column2: Ajahn Pasanno offers a live stream Dhamma talk and Q&A for the Buddhist Community at Stanford (BCAS).

column6: What is your favorite thing you've gotten from monastic life?
You really get to see the best of the human condition as a monastic. That's a real treat.
What advice do you have for students or graduates hoping to progess on the Noble Path towards Nibbāna while a student or in the workplace?
The pandemic has given rise to feelings of profound grief and loss in many of us. How can we best work with these emotions to cultivate well-being for ourselves and others?
Apart from social distancing, what are other ways to behave compassionately during this time when there's so much physical distance between us?
In your guided meditation you mentioned noticing, 'This is bearable.' When is it skillful to bear with and when it is skillful to put effort towards change, whether in action or in the mind?
How do we deal with a world full of view and opinions?
Sariputta doesn't approve of a teaching of the Buddha until he puts it into practice himself. Told by Ajahn Chah.
In what way are qualities and effects viral? Are right perception, right speech, right thought, and right action also viral?

You mentioned that ruminating on how one would like to change the world or the conditions around oneself can be a source of needless suffering. But there are times when one does want to work to change the world or the way society is organized for the sake of lovingkindness and alleviating suffering. How do we engage with those desire for change in a skillful way?
If one is going to commit oneself to change, one has to get used to looking at things from a big perspective, a perspective of 'How do we include rather than exclude?'
You want to approach a particular problem with an open a mind as possible and then see who might be willing and able to help.
